elements.content: The nickel 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (1,3,5-btc3-) coordination polymer, [Ni6(μ-OH2)4(1,3,5-btc)4(H2O)12] n (1), has been synthesized using a hydrothermal reaction. Trinuclear nickel cores constructed from the μ-OH2 and carboxylate bridges are linked by the 1,3,5-btc3- ligands, forming a two-dimensional network. The μ-OH2 molecules form strong hydrogen bonds with the free oxygens of the carboxylate groups in the trinuclear clusters. A structural phase transition occurs around 373 K and is categorized as a second-order phase transition.
elements.clean_text: The nickel 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (1,3,5-btc3-) coordination polymer, [Ni6(μ-OH2)4(1,3,5-btc)4(H2O)12] n  (1), has been synthesized using a hydrothermal reaction. Trinuclear nickel cores constructed from the μ-OH2 and carboxylate bridges are linked by the 1,3,5-btc3- ligands, forming a two-dimensional network. The μ-OH2 molecules form strong hydrogen bonds with the free oxygens of the carboxylate groups in the trinuclear clusters. A structural phase transition occurs around 373 K and is categorized as a second-order phase transition.

elements.content:
Strong intracluster hydrogen bonds are formed in the trinuclear core-based nickel 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate coordination polymer.

Introduction

The hydrogen bond, which was discovered almost 100 years ago, is the most important of all directional intermolecular interactions and is still a topic of intense scientific research. The reason for this long-lasting interest lies in the eminent importance of hydrogen bonds for the structure, function, and dynamics of a vast number of chemical systems, which range from inorganic and organic to biological chemistry. Coordination polymers constructed from transition metal ions and organic bridging ligands are available for the construction of novel hydrogen bonding interactions involving a variety of building blocks (metal ions, organic ligands, counter anions, solvents, etc.) and structures. In particular, the extended metal carboxylate coordination polymers, which have been an important research area in recent years because of their porous and magnetic properties, can produce characteristic hydrogen bonds via the proton-acceptor oxygen atoms of the carboxylate ligands. For example, the coordination polymer [Cu2(pzdc)2(pyz)] n (pzdc = pyrazine-2,3-dicarboxylate, pyz = pyrazine), which forms a pillared-layer structure with one-dimensional channels, has the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of the carboxylate parts in the pzdc2- ligand. Each end of guest acetylene molecules interacts with the uncoordinated oxygen atoms via hydrogen bonding interactions (O···H−C bond distance = 2.2 Å). This interaction is based not only on electrostatic attraction but also on the electron delocalization effect between H and O atoms. In this manuscript, we report the synthesis and crystal structure of the trinuclear core-based nickel(II) 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (1,3,5-btc3-) coordination polymer formulated as [Ni6(μ-OH2)4(1,3,5-btc)4(H2O)12] n (1), which shows strong intracluster μ-OH2···O2C− hydrogen bonding interactions, the strength of which changes with change in temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Strong intracluster hydrogen bonds are formed in the trinuclear core-based nickel 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate coordination polymer.

Introduction

The hydrogen bond, which was discovered almost 100 years ago, is the most important of all directional intermolecular interactions and is still a topic of intense scientific research. The reason for this long-lasting interest lies in the eminent importance of hydrogen bonds for the structure, function, and dynamics of a vast number of chemical systems, which range from inorganic and organic to biological chemistry. Coordination polymers constructed from transition metal ions and organic bridging ligands are available for the construction of novel hydrogen bonding interactions involving a variety of building blocks (metal ions, organic ligands, counter anions, solvents, etc.) and structures. In particular, the extended metal carboxylate coordination polymers, which have been an important research area in recent years because of their porous and magnetic properties, can produce characteristic hydrogen bonds via the proton-acceptor oxygen atoms of the carboxylate ligands. For example, the coordination polymer [Cu2(pzdc)2(pyz)] n  (pzdc = pyrazine-2,3-dicarboxylate, pyz = pyrazine), which forms a pillared-layer structure with one-dimensional channels, has the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of the carboxylate parts in the pzdc2- ligand. Each end of guest acetylene molecules interacts with the uncoordinated oxygen atoms via hydrogen bonding interactions (O⋅⋅⋅H-C bond distance = 2.2 Å). This interaction is based not only on electrostatic attraction but also on the electron delocalization effect between H and O atoms. In this manuscript, we report the synthesis and crystal structure of the trinuclear core-based nickel(II) 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (1,3,5-btc3-) coordination polymer formulated as [Ni6(μ-OH2)4(1,3,5-btc)4(H2O)12] n  (1), which shows strong intracluster μ-OH2⋅⋅⋅O2C- hydrogen bonding interactions, the strength of which changes with change in temperature.

elements.content: Chemicals were used as obtained without further purification. Elemental analysis (C and H) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer Model 240C elemental analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectral measurements were carried out using a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 2000 with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Rigaku Thermo Plus 2/TG-DTA8120 over the temperature range 298−773 K under an N2 atmosphere. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was performed on a Rigaku Thermo Plus 2/DSC8230 with an Al2O3 reference in the temperature range 298−423 K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals were used as obtained without further purification. Elemental analysis (C and H) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer Model 240C elemental analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectral measurements were carried out using a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 2000 with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Rigaku Thermo Plus 2/TG-DTA8120 over the temperature range 298-773 K under an N2 atmosphere. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was performed on a Rigaku Thermo Plus 2/DSC8230 with an Al2O3 reference in the temperature range 298-423 K.

elements.content: Preparation of 1. The synthesis was carried out in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container under autogenous pressure. The reactants were stirred briefly. The reaction of Na2MoO4·2H2O (242 mg, 1.00 mmol), NiCl2·6H2O (474 mg, 2.00 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (420 mg, 2.00 mmol), Na2SiO3 (61 mg, 0.500 mmol), and H2O (10 g, 0.555 mol) in the molar ratio 2:4:4:1:1110 at 150 °C for 24 h yielded green blocklike crystals, which were separated from the mixture by hand, washed with H2O and acetone, and dried in air. Anal. Calcd for C36H44Ni6O40:  C, 29.44; H, 3.02. Found:  C, 28.74; H, 2.99. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3575 m, 3367 m, 3264 m, 3150 m, 2680 w, 2551 w, 2110 m, 2051 m, 1647 m, 1614 s, 1552 s, 1523 s, 1436 s, 1366 s, 1208 w, 1147 m, 1108 m, 1065 w, 946 w, 926 w, 882 w, 847 w, 814 w, 802 w, 764 m, 713 s, 620 w, 548 w, 460 w, 419 w.
elements.clean_text: Preparation of 1. The synthesis was carried out in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container under autogenous pressure. The reactants were stirred briefly. The reaction of Na2MoO4⋅2H2O (242 mg, 1.00 mmol), NiCl2⋅6H2O (474 mg, 2.00 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (420 mg, 2.00 mmol), Na2SiO3 (61 mg, 0.500 mmol), and H2O (10 g, 0.555 mol) in the molar ratio 2:4:4:1:1110 at 150 °C for 24 h yielded green blocklike crystals, which were separated from the mixture by hand, washed with H2O and acetone, and dried in air. Anal. Calcd for C36H44Ni6O40: C, 29.44; H, 3.02. Found: C, 28.74; H, 2.99. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3575 m, 3367 m, 3264 m, 3150 m, 2680 w, 2551 w, 2110 m, 2051 m, 1647 m, 1614 s, 1552 s, 1523 s, 1436 s, 1366 s, 1208 w, 1147 m, 1108 m, 1065 w, 946 w, 926 w, 882 w, 847 w, 814 w, 802 w, 764 m, 713 s, 620 w, 548 w, 460 w, 419 w.

elements.content: X-ray Structural Analysis. X-ray diffraction measurements of 1 were performed on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). An empirical absorption correction was applied. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The structure was solved by direct methods (SHELXS-97) and expanded using Fourier techniques. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the bridging H2O molecules were refined isotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the 1,3,5-btc3- ligands were refined using the riding model. The refinements were carried out using full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2. All calculations were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package, except for refinement, which was performed using SHELXL-97. Crystal data are summarized in Table . The crystallographic data in CIF format are available from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC reference numbers 611322−611327 and 637431.
elements.clean_text: X-ray Structural Analysis. An empirical absorption correction was applied. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The structure was solved by direct methods (SHELXS-97) and expanded using Fourier techniques. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the bridging H2O molecules were refined isotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the 1,3,5-btc3- ligands were refined using the riding model. The refinements were carried out using full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2. All calculations were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package, except for refinement, which was performed using SHELXL-97. Crystal data are summarized in Table . The crystallographic data in CIF format are available from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC reference numbers 611322-611327 and 637431.

a   R = ∑||F o| − |F c||/∑|F o|. b R w = [∑w(|F o| − |F c|)2/∑wF o 2]1/2.

The nickel complex 1 was synthesized using a conventional hydrothermal method, which has been amply demonstrated in recent years to be particularly effective in the preparation of a wide variety of metastable cluster-based oxides and organic−inorganic hybrid materials. Several coordination polymers with the same building blocks as 1 have been reported to date. However, 1 has a novel, metastable assembly form. Therefore, the hydrothermal reaction is a good tool for the incorporation of unprecedented, characteristic hydrogen bonds into a coordination framework.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The nickel complex 1 was synthesized using a conventional hydrothermal method, which has been amply demonstrated in recent years to be particularly effective in the preparation of a wide variety of metastable cluster-based oxides and organic-inorganic hybrid materials. Several coordination polymers with the same building blocks as 1 have been reported to date. However, 1 has a novel, metastable assembly form. Therefore, the hydrothermal reaction is a good tool for the incorporation of unprecedented, characteristic hydrogen bonds into a coordination framework.

elements.content: The complex 1 was obtained by the reaction of NiCl2·6H2O, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, Na2SiO3, and Na2MoO4·2H2O in H2O media. The latter two reagents (Na2SiO3 and Na2MoO4·2H2O) are not involved in the construction of coordination framework. So, we tried to synthesize 1 in the absence of Na2MoO4·2H2O and Na2SiO3. However, we could not obtain single crystals of 1. Na2MoO4·2H2O and Na2SiO3 may contribute to pH control of the solution, because pH is one of very important factors in the construction of materials by a hydrothermal method.
elements.clean_text: The complex 1 was obtained by the reaction of NiCl2⋅6H2O, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, Na2SiO3, and Na2MoO4⋅2H2O  in H2O media. The latter two reagents (Na2SiO3 and Na2MoO4⋅2H2O) are not involved in the construction of coordination framework. So, we tried to synthesize 1 in the absence of Na2MoO4⋅2H2O and Na2SiO3. However, we could not obtain single crystals of 1. Na2MoO4⋅2H2O and Na2SiO3 may contribute to pH control of the solution, because pH is one of very important factors in the construction of materials by a hydrothermal method.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis at 143 K showed that 1 adopts a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure with a trinuclear nickel cluster, Ni3(μ-OH2)2(μ-O2C-)2(H2O)6(O2C-)4, as an inorganic building unit. There are two crystallographically independent trinuclear nickel clusters (cluster I and cluster II), both of which have similar coordination environments but distinguishable bond lengths and angles. The trinuclear nickel cluster I of 1 is shown in Figure a and b. The trinuclear unit consists of one central Ni(1) ion and two symmetry-related Ni(2) ions. The Ni(1) ion, which is located on the inversion center, is coordinated to two μ-OH2 molecules, two μ-O2C oxygen atoms, and two O2C oxygen atoms, which give rise to a slightly distorted octahedral coordination environment (the Ni(1)−O bond length is in the range 2.051−2.098 Å and the O−Ni(1)−O angle is in the range 89.0−92.3°). The Ni(2) center has a distorted octahedral environment with one μ-OH2 molecule, one μ-O2C oxygen atom, three H2O molecules, and one O2C oxygen atom (the Ni(2)−O bond length is in the range 2.038−2.086 Å, the O−Ni(2)−O angle (cis) is in the range 82.2−95.6°, and the O−Ni−O angle (trans) is in the range 170.4−175.6°). The intracluster Ni···Ni distances are 3.6343(2) and 3.5971(2) Å for clusters I and II, respectively. The 1,3,5-btc3- ligands bridge the trinuclear nickel clusters to form a 2D layer, as shown in Figure c. Intralayer π−π interactions acting between the benzene rings of the 1,3,5-btc3- ligands (shortest C···C distance = 3.3 Å) also contribute to stabilizing the 2D layer. It is well-known that the carboxylate group can show a variety of coordination modes. In 1, there are two types of coordination modes in the 1,3,5-btc3- ligand. Two carboxylate groups coordinate to nickel centers in a monodentate fashion, whereas another one bridges two nickel ions in a di-monodentate fashion. Each 2D layer assembles by hydrogen-bonding interactions between the trinuclear clusters. Between the 2D layers, the shortest C···C distance of 3.3 Å is observed, indicating the formation of interlayer π−π interactions between the benzene rings of the 1,3,5-btc3- ligands.

There are two crystallographically independent trinuclear nickel clusters (cluster I and cluster II), both of which have similar coordination environments but distinguishable bond lengths and angles. The trinuclear nickel cluster I of 1 is shown in Figure a and b. The trinuclear unit consists of one central Ni(1) ion and two symmetry-related Ni(2) ions. The Ni(1) ion, which is located on the inversion center, is coordinated to two μ-OH2 molecules, two μ-O2C oxygen atoms, and two O2C oxygen atoms, which give rise to a slightly distorted octahedral coordination environment (the Ni(1)-O bond length is in the range 2.051-2.098 Å and the O-Ni(1)-O angle is in the range 89.0-92.3°). The Ni(2) center has a distorted octahedral environment with one μ-OH2 molecule, one μ-O2C oxygen atom, three H2O molecules, and one O2C oxygen atom (the Ni(2)-O bond length is in the range 2.038-2.086 Å, the O-Ni(2)-O angle (cis) is in the range 82.2-95.6°, and the O-Ni-O angle (trans) is in the range 170.4-175.6°). The intracluster Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distances are 3.6343(2) and 3.5971(2) Å for clusters I and II, respectively. The 1,3,5-btc3- ligands bridge the trinuclear nickel clusters to form a 2D layer, as shown in Figure c. Intralayer π-π interactions acting between the benzene rings of the 1,3,5-btc3- ligands (shortest C⋅⋅⋅C distance = 3.3 Å) also contribute to stabilizing the 2D layer. It is well-known that the carboxylate group can show a variety of coordination modes. In 1, there are two types of coordination modes in the 1,3,5-btc3- ligand. Two carboxylate groups coordinate to nickel centers in a monodentate fashion, whereas another one bridges two nickel ions in a di-monodentate fashion. Each 2D layer assembles by hydrogen-bonding interactions between the trinuclear clusters. Between the 2D layers, the shortest C⋅⋅⋅C distance of 3.3 Å is observed, indicating the formation of interlayer π-π interactions between the benzene rings of the 1,3,5-btc3- ligands.

elements.content: (a) Line drawing and (b) ORTEP view of the trinuclear nickel cluster. The terminal H2O molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. The dotted lines indicate the hydrogen bonds. (c) View of the 2D layer projected along the c-axis. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Line drawing and (b) ORTEP view of the trinuclear nickel cluster. The terminal H2O molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. The dotted lines indicate the hydrogen bonds. (c) View of the 2D layer projected along the c-axis. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: All of the bridging and terminal H2O molecules are involved in hydrogen-bonding interactions. Table shows a list of the hydrogen bond distances and angles. The H2O molecules coordinating to the terminal nickel ions of the trinuclear clusters form “moderate” hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups in nearest-neighbor 2D layers, that is, interlayer (intercluster) hydrogen bonding interactions. A hydrogen bond O(9)···O(19) formed between the terminal H2O molecules is also observed. On the other hand, the bridging H2O molecules afford intracluster hydrogen bonding interactions with the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups, as shown in Figure b. The bond distances of 2.541(2) and 2.527(2) Å are very short, indicating the formation of “strong” hydrogen bonds. The bond angles of O−H···O are close to 180° (164−171°). IR spectra measured at 293 K clearly show the characteristic O−H stretching bands νs in the wide range of 1800−3700 cm-1, as shown in Figure . In particular, 1 has a broad O−H stretching band around 2100 cm-1, which is not observed in the starting material, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and its sodium salt. Therefore, the intracluster O···O hydrogen bond distances of 2.541(2) and 2.527(2) Å probably correspond to the νs bands near 2100 cm-1. It is apparent that for the O···O hydrogen bonds, a linear relationship only holds for the strong bonds with νs from 2700 to 750 cm-1 and O···O from 2.60 to 2.45 Å. A linear relationship is also obtained for strong hydrogen bonds observed in this work.

A hydrogen bond O(9)⋅⋅⋅O(19) formed between the terminal H2O molecules is also observed. On the other hand, the bridging H2O molecules afford intracluster hydrogen bonding interactions with the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups, as shown in Figure b. The bond distances of 2.541(2) and 2.527(2) Å are very short, indicating the formation of "strong" hydrogen bonds. The bond angles of O-H⋅⋅⋅O are close to 180° (164-171°). It is apparent that for the O⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds, a linear relationship only holds for the strong bonds with νs from 2700 to 750 cm-1 and O⋅⋅⋅O from 2.60 to 2.45 Å. A linear relationship is also obtained for strong hydrogen bonds observed in this work.

a  Symmetry code:  (1) x, y − 1, z; (2) x − 1, y, z; (3) x − 1, y + 1, z; (4) x, y + 1, z; (5) −x, −y + 1, −z; (6) x + 1, y, z; (7) x + 1, y − 1, z; (8) −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 1.

In the trinuclear cluster, neighboring nickel ions are bridged by the H2O molecule and the carboxylate group of the 1,3,5-btc3- ligand. The Lewis basicity of an H2O molecule is weaker than that of a 1,3,5-btc3- ligand. Therefore, to stabilize the trinuclear cluster, it is necessary to improve the Lewis basicity of the bridged H2O molecule. Each nickel ion is coordinated to the monodentate carboxylate groups in addition to the bridged H2O molecules. Coordination-free oxygen atoms of such carboxylate groups can interact with bridged H2O molecules via “strong” hydrogen bonds. Because the protons of the bridged H2O molecules are attracted to the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups, the Lewis basicity of the bridged H2O molecule increases. Hence, we consider that “strong” hydrogen bonds form to stabilize the trinuclear clusters.
elements.clean_text: In the trinuclear cluster, neighboring nickel ions are bridged by the H2O molecule and the carboxylate group of the 1,3,5-btc3- ligand. The Lewis basicity of an H2O molecule is weaker than that of a 1,3,5-btc3- ligand. Therefore, to stabilize the trinuclear cluster, it is necessary to improve the Lewis basicity of the bridged H2O molecule. Each nickel ion is coordinated to the monodentate carboxylate groups in addition to the bridged H2O molecules. Coordination-free oxygen atoms of such carboxylate groups can interact with bridged H2O molecules via "strong" hydrogen bonds. Because the protons of the bridged H2O molecules are attracted to the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups, the Lewis basicity of the bridged H2O molecule increases. Hence, we consider that "strong" hydrogen bonds form to stabilize the trinuclear clusters.

elements.content: TGA was performed to check the stability of the coordinated H2O molecules. The TGA curve of 1 shows two main events between room temperature and 773 K (see the Supporting Information). The first (473−623 K) is assigned to the removal of all H2O molecules (observed 18.1%, calculated 19.6%). The second event (693−733 K) corresponds to the elimination of the organic component. The high elimination temperature of the H2O molecules indicates that they are strongly held via coordination and hydrogen bonds.
elements.clean_text: TGA was performed to check the stability of the coordinated H2O molecules. The TGA curve of 1 shows two main events between room temperature and 773 K (see the Supporting Information). The first (473-623 K) is assigned to the removal of all H2O molecules (observed 18.1%, calculated 19.6%). The second event (693-733 K) corresponds to the elimination of the organic component. The high elimination temperature of the H2O molecules indicates that they are strongly held via coordination and hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the crystal structure was checked to investigate the change of hydrogen-bonding interactions. At 143 K, there are two crystallographically independent trinuclear clusters (I and II) whose bond lengths and angles are different from each other. As the temperature increases, the difference in the bond distances of cluster I and cluster II becomes small. At 373 K, a structural phase transition occurs and only one crystallographically independent trinuclear cluster I‘ is observed. In accordance with this phase transition, the unit cell volume reduces by almost half. After the phase transition (at 393 K), the shortest intracluster Ni···Ni distance becomes 3.6118(2) Å, this value being midway between those of cluster I and cluster II at 143 K. Figure shows the temperature dependence of the hydrogen-bond distances in the trinuclear clusters. The intracluster hydrogen bonds change as the temperature increases. After the phase transition, the “strong” hydrogen bonds of 2.524(2) Å (at 393 K) are still retained. The intercluster hydrogen bonds also change as the temperature increases. This structural phase transition is reversible, which was checked by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. DSC measurement indicates no clear latent heat in the temperature range of 298 to 423 K (see the Supporting Information). Therefore, this phase transition may be categorized as a second-order phase transition, which has been frequently observed in organic polymers.
elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of the crystal structure was checked to investigate the change of hydrogen-bonding interactions. At 143 K, there are two crystallographically independent trinuclear clusters (I and II) whose bond lengths and angles are different from each other. As the temperature increases, the difference in the bond distances of cluster I and cluster II becomes small. At 373 K, a structural phase transition occurs and only one crystallographically independent trinuclear cluster I‘ is observed. In accordance with this phase transition, the unit cell volume reduces by almost half. After the phase transition (at 393 K), the shortest intracluster Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance becomes  3.6118(2) Å, this value being midway between those of cluster I and cluster II at 143 K. Figure  shows the temperature dependence of the hydrogen-bond distances in the trinuclear clusters. The intracluster hydrogen bonds change as the temperature increases. After the phase transition, the "strong" hydrogen bonds of 2.524(2) Å (at 393 K) are still retained. The intercluster hydrogen bonds also change as the temperature increases. This structural phase transition is reversible, which was checked by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. DSC measurement indicates no clear latent heat in the temperature range of 298 to 423 K (see the Supporting Information). Therefore, this phase transition may be categorized as a second-order phase transition, which has been frequently observed in organic polymers.

elements.content: A novel trinuclear core-based nickel 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate coordination polymer, [Ni6(μ-OH2)4(1,3,5-btc)4(H2O)12] n (1), has been structurally characterized using X-ray diffraction measurements. The trinuclear clusters, in which the NiII ions are bridged by the μ-OH2 and the μ-O2C units, are linked by the organic 1,3,5-btc3- ligands to form 2D layers. In the trinuclear clusters, strong hydrogen-bonding interactions are formed between the bridged μ-H2O molecules and the coordination-free oxygen atoms of the 1,3,5-btc3- ligands. IR spectra clearly show the characteristic O−H stretching band around 2100 cm-1, which is consistent with a formation of strong hydrogen bonds. At 373 K, 1 shows a structural phase transition categorized as a second-order phase transition, which was confirmed by the DSC measurement. The low-temperature phase contains two crystallographically independent units, whereas in the high-temperature phase, the two independent units have exactly the same environment. These results indicate that a hydrothermal reaction is a good tool for the construction of metal carboxylate coordination polymers with a variety of hydrogen bonds and structural bistability. Work is now in progress to synthesize coordination frameworks with characteristic hydrogen-bonding interactions using a hydrothermal reaction.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A novel trinuclear core-based nickel 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate coordination polymer, [Ni6(μ-OH2)4(1,3,5-btc)4(H2O)12] n  (1), has been structurally characterized using X-ray diffraction measurements. The trinuclear clusters, in which the NiII ions are bridged by the μ-OH2 and the μ-O2C units, are linked by the organic 1,3,5-btc3- ligands to form 2D layers. In the trinuclear clusters, strong hydrogen-bonding interactions are formed between the bridged μ-H2O molecules and the coordination-free oxygen atoms of the 1,3,5-btc3- ligands. IR spectra clearly show the characteristic O-H stretching band around 2100 cm-1, which is consistent with a formation of strong hydrogen bonds. At 373 K, 1 shows a structural phase transition categorized as a second-order phase transition, which was confirmed by the DSC measurement. The low-temperature phase contains two crystallographically independent units, whereas in the high-temperature phase, the two independent units have exactly the same environment. These results indicate that a hydrothermal reaction is a good tool for the construction of metal carboxylate coordination polymers with a variety of hydrogen bonds and structural bistability. Work is now in progress to synthesize coordination frameworks with characteristic hydrogen-bonding interactions using a hydrothermal reaction.

cln_elements.content: Preparation of 1. The synthesis was carried out in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container under autogenous pressure. The reactants were stirred briefly. The reaction of Na2MoO4·2H2O (242 mg, 1.00 mmol), NiCl2·6H2O (474 mg, 2.00 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (420 mg, 2.00 mmol), Na2SiO3 (61 mg, 0.500 mmol), and H2O (10 g, 0.555 mol) in the molar ratio 2:4:4:1:1110 at 150 °C for 24 h yielded green blocklike crystals, which were separated from the mixture by hand, washed with H2O and acetone, and dried in air. Anal. Calcd for C36H44Ni6O40:  C, 29.44; H, 3.02. Found:  C, 28.74; H, 2.99. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3575 m, 3367 m, 3264 m, 3150 m, 2680 w, 2551 w, 2110 m, 2051 m, 1647 m, 1614 s, 1552 s, 1523 s, 1436 s, 1366 s, 1208 w, 1147 m, 1108 m, 1065 w, 946 w, 926 w, 882 w, 847 w, 814 w, 802 w, 764 m, 713 s, 620 w, 548 w, 460 w, 419 w.

Anal. Calcd for C36H44Ni6O40: C, 29.44; H, 3.02. Found: C, 28.74; H, 2.99. cln_elements.content: TGA was performed to check the stability of the coordinated H2O molecules. The TGA curve of 1 shows two main events between room temperature and 773 K (see the Supporting Information). The first (473−623 K) is assigned to the removal of all H2O molecules (observed 18.1%, calculated 19.6%). The second event (693−733 K) corresponds to the elimination of the organic component. The high elimination temperature of the H2O molecules indicates that they are strongly held via coordination and hydrogen bonds.

metadata.title:
Formation of Strong OH2···-O2C Hydrogen Bonds in a Trinuclear
Core-Based Nickel 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylate Coordination
Polymer
